## 'Speedy' Intro

::: {style="font-size: 32pt"}

- Ocean warming as a driver for shifts in species’ habitats 

<br>

- North Pacific Ocean is changing: considerable documentation of pelagic animals response to anomalous conditions & established expansion of subtropical gyre [(Polovina et al. 2011)]{style="font-size: 22pt"}

<br>

- Most studies: short-term or simulations... but we have a unique data set (+2 decades) to explore these changes 

:::

## Questions

1. How do Sept turtle-18°C SST positions compare between historic (1997-2012) and 2023 turtles in the NE Pacific? Is this a northward expansion?

<br>

2. 2023 was an unprecedented year. Are turtles responding to year-to-year variability or longer-term trends in ocean warming?
    - H1: Year to year variability but no long-term trend in seasonal bounds of gyre & turtle habitat

    - H2: Expansion of summer bounds (ie Sept) due to rapid warming 

    - H3: Expansion of summer and winter bounds (ie Sept and Mar)

## Results

- Historically ~18C SST and loggerhead forage habitat moves seasonally from about 30 N lat in March to about 40 N lat in September

<br>

- Tagging release in 2023 NE Pacific showed loggerheads still tracking 18C SST but reaching several degrees further north than historic data set

<br>

- Analysis of 18C SST location (1985 - 2023) shows March and Sept isotherms moving north over time with loggerheads also moving northward, tracking 18C SST 

<br>

- This northerly shift of 18C SST means greater migration distance for loggerheads to travel. What will this mean for distance to coastal habitat?
